turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Okay, I really need to book a flight for next week. I'm trying to get from Chicago to Miami, leaving on Monday, November 11th, and coming back Friday, November 15th. Can you find me some options? Non-stop is a big plus.

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: Certainly. I can search for flights from Chicago to Miami, departing on Monday, November 11th, and returning on Friday, November 15th. I will prioritize non-stop options. Searching now...

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Okay, thanks. This is a last-minute trip, so I'm a bit stressed about finding something affordable. Also, can you tell me, if a flight has a layover in Atlanta, how much time do I *really* need to connect if my first flight is on time? I heard Hartsfield-Jackson is huge and confusing, and I don't want to miss my connecting flight. This seems really tricky.

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: Finding affordable last-minute flights can be challenging, but I'll do my best. Regarding connecting in Atlanta (ATL), while it is a large airport, airlines typically set a minimum connection time (MCT) based on typical passenger flow. For domestic connections at ATL, the MCT is usually around 45-50 minutes, assuming your arriving flight is on time and you don't need to change terminals requiring the Plane Train or re-clear security (which isn't common for standard domestic connections). However, allowing at least 1 hour 15 minutes to 1 hour 30 minutes provides a much more comfortable buffer, especially if there are any minor delays or if you are unfamiliar with the airport layout. Always check the specific airline's recommended connection time for your itinerary.
